title: SB 1.18.32-33 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 21-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjali Shalakaya
Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvichesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shri Vasadi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaiva Narottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we discussed
the 32nd and 33rd verses of the 18th chapter of the 1st canto of Shreemad Bhagavatam.
This chapter is entitled Maharaj Pariksit Cursed by a Brahmana Boy.
The incidents leading to this cursing are being discussed in these verses.
So the 32nd verse
Tasyaputro Atitejasvi Viharan Balako Arbhakaihi
Rajnagam Praapitam Tatam Shrutvata Tredam Abhravit
The meaning of these 32nd verses
This sage had a son who was very powerful being a Brahmana's son.
While he was playing with inexperienced boys, he heard of his father's distress just occasioned
by the king.
Then and there, the boys started to play with him.
Then and there, the boys started to play with him.
Then and there, the boys started to play with him.
Then and there, the boys started to play with him.
Indeed,ï¿½
In the Purport Shrila Prabhupada says
Due to Maharaj Pariksit's good government even a boy of tender age who was playing
with other inexperienced boys could become as powerful as a qualified Brahmana.
This boy was known as Sringi and he achieved good training in Brahmacharya by his father
He could be as powerful as a brahmana even at that age.
But because the age of Kali was seeking an opportunity to spoil the culture to heritage of the four orders of life,
the inexperienced boy gave a chance for the age of Kali to enter into the field of Vedic culture.
Hatred of the lower orders of life began from this brahmana boy under the influence of Kali
and thus cultural life began to dwindle day after day.
So this is the explanation given here.
How the age of Kali things deteriorate to earth.
To a great extent, that the brahmanas who are supposed to be the head of the society,
they become degraded and they look down upon the other sections of society.
Just like this boy, he wrongly thinks that he is the head of the society.
He thought that the king had overstepped his position and he cursed the king.
That's going to be explained later in the next few verses.
He shouldn't have cursed the king, but he did so.
And it happened under the influence of Kali.
He was still seeking a chance to enter into the field of Vedic culture, as Shruta Prabhupada says here.
The first victim of brahmanical injustice was Maharaj Pariksit.
And thus, the protection given by the king against the onslaught of Kali was slackened.
We should remember how Kali was trying to enter the kingdom of Pariksit.
And Pariksit prevented that by, first of all, threatening to kill Kali because Kali Purusha was harming the coven bull.
And when Kali Purusha surrendered, Pariksit Maharaj had to give shelter as a king.
So he said, you cannot stay in my kingdom because you are a friend of a religion.
And then Kali Purusha was...
Kali Purusha was given, still, when he begged for some place, he was given four places, places where meat-eating, intoxication, gambling and illicit sex are going on.
And Kali Purusha could not find any such place in Pariksit's kingdom.
So good was Pariksit's rule.
And then Kali Purusha was given a fifth place when he couldn't find any place.
He was given the place where gold was found.
And gold is accumulated without being used for spiritual purposes.
And that way Kali Purusha was given some place.
But even then, Pariksit protected the citizens by engaging their stored-up wealth, stored-up gold in Sankirtan Yagna.
If we want to protect ourselves against the evil influence of Kali,
we should employ 50% of our wealth in propagating Sankirtana.
So this way Kali cannot influence the people of this age.
So here, the description is that Maharaj Pariksit was the victim of Brahmanical injustice.
Wrongly, he was cursed.
And that's how the onslaught of Kali was slacked through this injustice.
The 33rd words,
Aho Adharma Palaanam.
Peevnam Balibhujamiva.
Swamin Yagam Yad Dasanam.
Dvarapanam Shunamiva.
The meaning of this 33rd verse is,
The Brahmana's son Shungi said,
Oh, just look at the sins of the rulers who,
like crows and watchdogs at the door,
perpetrate sins against their mothers.
Oh, just look at the sins of the rulers who, like crows and watchdogs at the door, perpetrate sins against their mothers.
Contrary to the principles governing servants.
Contrary to the principles governing servants.
So Shungi, this Brahmana's son,
when he heard that his father was insulted by the king,
who put a dead snake around his father's neck.
So he became very, very angry.
And what is he saying?
Look at these rulers.
What is their position?
They are like crows and watchdogs at the door of the Brahmanas.
And instead of behaving properly as a servant of the Brahmanas,
they are perpetrating sins against their masters.
So in the parpochana Prabhupada says,
The Brahmanas are considered to be the head and brains of the social body.
And the Chakras are considered to be the arms of the social body.
And the Chakras are considered to be the arms of the social body.
And the Chakras are considered to be the arms of the social body.
The arms are required to protect the body from all harm.
The arms are required to protect the body from all harm.
But the arms must act according to the directions of the head and brain.
See the comparison is made,
the orders, the spiritual orders, or the social orders.
Brahmana, Chakra, and Vaishya, Shudra.
They are compared to the four parts of our own body.
It's like we have got the head and brain,
we got the arms,
we have got
the belly and we got the legs.
So brahmanas are compared to the head and brains of the social body.
Most important.
And kshatriyas are considered to be the arms.
So the arms are required to protect the body from all harm
but the arms must act
according to the directions of the head and brain.
That's how this body is organized.
Same way society should be organized like that.
That is a natural arrangement made by the supreme order
for it is confirmed in the Bhagavad Gita
that four social orders or castes
namely the brahmanas, the kshatriyas, the vaisyas and shudras
are set up according to quality
and work done by them.
This is the statement of the Bhagavad Gita,
the fourth chapter.
Krishna explains this.
So according to guna and karma it has to be set up.
Naturally the son of a brahmana has a good chance to become a brahmana
by the direction of his qualified father
as
the son of a brahmana.
The son of a brahmana or a medical practitioner
has a very good chance to become a qualified medical practitioner.
So the caste system is quite scientific.
The son must take advantage of the father's qualification
and thus become a brahmana or a medical practitioner
and not otherwise.
Without being qualified
one cannot become a brahmana or a medical practitioner
and that is the verdict of all scriptures and social orders.
You see,
it is true that the son of a brahmana has a good opportunity
to learn from his father
and become a qualified brahmana.
But without the qualification he cannot claim I am a brahmana.
What is happening nowadays?
People are claiming to be brahmanas
without being trained,
without being trained,
without being qualified.
And that is where the whole system has become topsy-turvy.
So Prabhupada points out here,
Herein Shrunge, a qualified son of a great brahmana,
attained the required brahmanical power
both by birth and by training.
But he was lacking in culture
because he was an inexperienced boy.
Even though he was powerful,
he was not sufficiently experienced
how to utilize the power that he had acquired.
By the influence of Kali,
the son of a brahmana became puffed up
with brahmanical power
and thus wrongly compared Maharaj Pariksit
to crows and watchdogs.
This comparison is completely inappropriate.
Just because this boy, inexperienced boy,
was very proud of his brahmanical power.
The king is certainly the watchdog of the state
in the sense that he keeps vigilant eyes
over the border of the state
for its protection and defense.
But to address him as a watchdog
is a sign of a less cultured boy.
He is supposed to protect,
he is supposed to govern
the country or the state or the province.
But he cannot be treated
like a low-class servant
the way Sringi is thinking
that the king has become an upstart.
Thus the downfall of the brahmanical powers began
as they gave importance to birthright
without culture.
If a brahmana is uncultured
then he may wrongly claim to be a brahmana
simply by birthright.
I am born in a brahmana family
therefore I should be treated as a brahmana.
But what about your culture?
What about your education?
What about your training?
What about your qualification?
What about your experience?
All these are important factors.
The downfall of the brahmana caste
began in the age of Kali.
According to scriptures
5000 years back Kali Yuga began
and that is when unqualified people
started claiming
this because of birthright
that we are brahmanas
we should be respected as brahmanas
by all the others.
Whereas the others are observing
these brahmanas are not qualified
and they are wrongly claiming
to be brahmanas.
So they started losing respect
and that is when everything
became topsy-turvy.
Since brahmanas are the heads
of the social order
all other orders of society
also began to deteriorate.
The brahmana should give directions
to the other orders of society
which are triyas, vashyas and shudras.
But brahmanas themselves are not
qualified.
How can they give directions
proper directions to the other orders?
So the other orders also
start deteriorating.
This beginning of brahmanical deterioration
was highly deplored
by the father Shringi
as we will find.
So what is Shringi's father's reaction
that we will see in the next few verses.
I will stop here.
Thank you.
Hare Krishna.
Thank you.
